sourceDesc.p: This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed Inns of Court collection. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
For a full list of REED collections, editors, executive board members, and staff, please visit http://reed.utoronto.ca/people

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the taxon prefix are pointers to entities in the taxonomy.xml file. For example, taxon:church dereferences to taxonomy.xml#church.
Private URIs using the gloss prefix are pointers to entities in the glossary.xml file. For example, gloss:histrio-1 dereferences to glossary.xml#histrio-1.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

div.head: f 80(30 November)
div.ab: Memorandum quod ad istud parliamentum concordatum est quod non custodiet hoc anno tempus Natalis prout ex antiquo sed computabitur illis qui moribunt pro vacacione Et allocati erunt Societati pro istruonibus sicut fuerunt Anno preterito vel per discrecionem &c...

Concordatum est quod Societas haberent habuerint pro purific ‸tempore Natalis domini vnum aprum preter a Sheld & ij roundes Et quod communes computantur Septimatim Et quod illi qui sunt communitores onerentur de omnibus expensis exceptis istruonibus qui he habebunt xx s. Et excepto Apro superdicto

div.head: f 89(24 November)
div.ab: Item ordinatum fuit quod Comitiua Interioris Templ qui custodiet Communes tempore Natalis domini pro futuro allocentur vnus le bore & pro lez stipend de lez mynstrellys tempore Natalis domini xxx s. & pro vno Cariete de lez Cooles pro focalio…

div.head: f 114v(16 November)
div.ab: Ad hunc parliamentum Iohannes Tofton vnus Comitiui exoneratus de vacacione Natalis domini Anno xxxjoo Henrici viijo & de officio vnius Maiestrorum de le revelles ad dictum festum natalis domini & pro hoc dedit Cometiue interioris Temple iij li. vj s. viij d. Soluti ad manum Dauid brook Tezerarij &c
The date of this parliament is given as 14 November in Inderwick (p 122); however, this has been cancelled in the MS and corrected to 16 November (f 114).

row.cell: Magistri revelorumMagistri revelorum: braced pointing right toMagistri...kebell
Magistri cusacke/ skiddye evans et kebell

div.ab: Folio damaged by post-World War II fire; the date is supplied from Inderwick.
This entry occurs first on f 135 among unformatted entries, is there cancelled, and has been rewritten here in the traditional layout.

div.head: f 139(20 November)
div.ab: Memorandum yt ys ordered at this present parliament that no graund Christenmas shalbe kept in this house for this yere for that the house hathe byn at greate charge in buildynge of a newe kytchen and other charges besydes so by reason by reason of those Charges to the Companye hyt was thought good not to charge them therewithe any further/

Memorandum that leeke Mr Raphe leeke ys for the Summe of xl s. ys payd to the Thresorer ys dyscharged of the office of one of the Masters of the Revel appereth in the dogget of vacacions where he was amercyd v li. default for not exercysing of the sayd office &c.

No Inner Temple appointments to the office of master of the revels are recorded for this or subsequent years. Christmas officers hereafter are limited to marshals, stewards, and butlers. Compare to Middle Temple, where such records cease at the end of the reign of Mary.

div.head: f 164(4 February)
div.ab: It is ordered yat Masters withwith: ie, Robert Wythe guynes lucas manser &c shall take & bryng into this howse at the nex Parlement a Rekenyng of all Sommes of mony layd owt by any in Christmas tymes or at Candelmas for any maskes. playes. disgysynges or other lyke

div.head: f 164v
div.ab: last set forth by him.

div.head: f 204v(15 June)
div.ab: TuchingeMusicions wages 27 Ianuarii 25 Elizabethe/ the sute of the musicions to haue allowans of ther Wages of xx s. at the feast of all saintes last past it is ordered that the same shalbe payde & allowed albeit no comens was then kepte
The marginal note is a cross-reference to a payment made to musicians on 27 January 1582/3 (see p 106).

div.head: f 220v(27 January)
div.ab:
Mr Hallhallowance musicions the musicion is to haue the lyke Allowance for Michaelmas terme last, as he hath heretofore had in the same tearme when the terme hath not holden by reason of the plage.
vide 15 Iunij 20 Elizabethe/
Folio damaged in post–World War  fire; the date is supplied from Inderwick. The cross-reference is to the 1577–8 entry (p 101).

div.head: f 11(8 February)
div.ab: Whereas in this present Hilary terme Candelmas daye was vpon the mondaye and by reason therof the musicians attended two night and one wholl daye, It is agreed that they shall receive fowrty shillinges in recompense of their service done./ And for that they doe greatly complaine that they receive great damage for that duringe the tyme of Christmas they neither be reteyned in service here as before they have ben nor yet have convenient notice gyven unto them from the fellowshippe of this howse of their determynacion so as they maye provyde for themselfes elsewhere: It is also ordered that they shall have sufficient notice gyven unto them three weekes before Christmas at the least whither this howse will vse their service or not and if noe such notice be made vnto them it shall be lawful for them to provyde for themselfes elswhere duringe all the saide tyme of Christmas.

div.head: f 99(10 February)
div.ab: Whereas, Private Comons taken awaie in Christmas great disorders doe growe in this howse and greate losse and detryment to many yonge gentlemen fellowes of the same, by reason of kepinge pryvate Commons in Christmas It is at this parliament ordered That from henceforth there shalbee noe pryvate Commons kept in this howse in the tyme of Christmas, but that the Comons of the howse shall henceforth bee contynued dureing Christmas tyme as in other tymes of the yeare without any dyceinge or other disorder. Neither shall there bee any Lorde or breaking vpp of any mans Chamber vppon payne that every person which hereafter shall attempt any such thinge shall incurre the danger and penaltie of the former orders in that behalf heretofore made./

And Noe playes one festyvall days.for that great disorder & scurrilytie is brought into this howse by lewde & lasciuious playes. It is likewise ordered in this parliament that from henceforth there shalbe no more playes in this howse either vpon the ffeast of all Sainctes or Candlemas day, but the same from henceforth to bee vtterly taken awaie and abolyshed

div.head: f 105v(24 November)
div.ab: Where[of] The order for layinge downe of playes repealed.of late yeares vpon the two festivall dayes of All Saintes and Candlemasse playes haue beene vsed after dinner for recreacion which haue lately beene layd downe by order in Parliament It is now ordered that the same order shall henceforth stand repealed.

div.head: f 112v(4 May)
div.ab: fforasmuche it is found by experience That the vtterbarresters, of this howse, as alsoe other gentlemen vnder the barre doe vsually vnder hand & secretlie contrarie to the Statutes & orders of this howse, make sale of theire Chambers, for great sommes of money, and convert the same to theire owne privat vse to the great preiudice and state of this howse And for that contrariewise It is seen from the experience of other howses of Courte, that throughe sale made of Chambers by the governors of such howse muche benefitt and proffitte hath growne to the general state of the same: with furderance and due content of the Studentes there, And forasmuche as this howse att this present is muche indebted by reason of the late showe and sportes made by the gentlemen of this howse before his highnes att whitehall Amountinge in Charges vnto the howse (over and besides the stocke of this howse,) not soe litle as xijC li. which requires somme extraordynarie and unwonted course of supply, but noe meanes as yet noe meanes as yet:for no meanes are as yetdiscerned therein soe fittinge as suche husbandlye course of admittances, Be it therefore enacted att this present ‸parliament that hencefourth all admittances into anye Chamber or Chambers of this howse in possession or Revercion (other then Benchers Chambers priviledged by acte of parliament) shalbe made from tyme to tyme by acte of parliament, and not by the Threasourer of this ‸howse allone as heretofore haue ben, and that all admittances otherwise had or made shalbe voyde, And it is furder enacted that vppon everye suche admittance by acte of parliament the partie or parties to be admitted shall over and above the former vsuall & accustomed fine for an admittance paye vnto the Threasourer of this howse suche furder somme or sommes of money for such Chamber or Chambers as shalbe then assessed and sett downe for suche admittances as the worth of the chamber or chambers will in the iudgement of such parliament afford to be sold betweene partie and partie, Nevertheles it is alsoe furder enacted that everye person soe admitted and payinge suche somme of money shall att any tyme after vppon his surrender of suche his interest in suche Chamber or Chambers, wherein he shall stand soe admitted as aforesaid, haue repaide backe vnto him by the Threasourer of this howse three full partes in foure partes devided of the wholl fine or somme of money which he shall haue soe formerlie paid and disbursed as aforesaid, And this acte to be sufficient warrant and discharge to suche Threasourer for the tyme beinge in that behaulf,: Provided alwayes that this acte or anie thinge therein contayned shall not extend to anye Chamber, Chambers, or Rowmes, wherein anye of this Socyetie haue anie graunt by anye acte of parliament, but that everye suche person and persons theire executors and assignes shall haue Contynue and enioye there said Chambers and Romes, whereof and wherein they stand soe admitted with all priviledges and benefittes in as lardge and beneficiall manner to all purposes as the same were graunted vnto them or to anie other vnder whome they Clayme the same by force of anye acte of parliament heretofore made anye thinge in this acte to the contrarie notwithstandinge/

The phrase ‘late showe and sportes’ (p 151, l.41) refers to Beaumont’s Masque of the Inner Temple and Gray’s Inn, performed in the Banqueting House, Whitehall, on 20 February 1612/13, following the marriage of Princess Elizabeth and the count palatine. The figure ‘xijC li.’(£1200), if doubled to allow for Gray’s Inn’s share, tallies roughly with the total of £2255 8s 11d calculated by Orbison (ed), Collections 12, p 7, to have been the cost of George Chapman’s masque presented by the Middle Temple and Lincoln’s Inn for the same occasion.

div.head: f 120(10 July)
div.ab: At this Parliament yt is ordered that Mr Lumley the draper shallbe paid fower powndes twelve shillinges & sixe pence, for scarlett ymployed for the Marshall at the Maske

div.head: f 219-19v(12 November)
div.ab: Whereas Ayde Rolle for the Masquethere having bene no representacion of any Maske or other Shewe before the Kings Maiestie by the fower Inns of Court or any of them sythence his Highnesse accesse vnto the Crowne, a Consultacion hath bene latelie had by the severall Benchers in theire severall howses touching the same Wherevpon it is vnanimous agreed by them, that a Maske shall bee ioynt presented in this next Christmas before his Maiestie, att the equall charges of the sai fower howses. It is therefore nowe ordered and enacted att this parliament That for the raysing and leavying of moneys towardes the defraying of the said Charge everie ffellowe of this howse shall bee taxed to paye as followeth, vizt./

Everie Bencher of this howse to paye the summe of five powndes.
Everie Vtter Barrister of this howse being seaven yeares standing of the Barr or vpward fiftie shillinges./
Everie Vtter Barrister of this howse which is vnder seaven yeares standing of the Barr fortie shillinges
Everie Gentleman vnder the Barr who hath bene in Commons within one yeare last past or is nowe in Commons or shall bee in Commons within one yeare next ensuinge to paye twentie shillinges And euerie such Gentleman vnder the Barr who hath a Chamber in the howse to paye twentie shillinges although he hath not bene in Commons within one year last past as aforesaid. And that such as are hereafter named who have or keepe the severall Offices hereafter mencioned within this howse shall paye (over and besides the summes aforesaid) for and in respect of theire said severall Offices the severall summes following, That is to saye/

Richard Brownlowe Esquier for his Office of Cheiffe Prothonotary of the Common pleas five powndes./
Robert Henly and Samuell Wightwick Esquiers for the Kinges Bench Office ten powndes Thomas ffanshawe Esquier for the Crowne Office six powndes thirteene shillinges and fower pence
Mr Hugh Audley for the Office of Wardes and Liveries ten powndes
Mr William Blage for his Office of Cyrographer Ten powndes
Mr William Rolfe for his Office of Clark of the Warrantes six powndes thirteene shillinges and fower pence./ |
Mr Richard Barringer for his Office of Philozer three powndes six shillinges and eight pence
Mr Matthewe Cradock for his Office of Clark of Assizes fortie shillinges
Mr ffrancis Williamson for his Office of Clark of Assizes fortie shillinges
Mr Humfrey Streete for his Office of Auditor three powndes six shillinges and eight pence

And it is further ordered that the Cheiffe Butler shall make a Rolle of the names of all such ffellowes of this howse as are chargeable with the paymentes aforesaid and collect the same forthwith, and from tyme to tyme deliver such summes of money as he shall collect vpon the said Rolle vnto the handes of Mr Willis one of the Benchers of this howse, whoe togeather with Mr Cesar of the Barr and Mr Pollard of the Masters Commons are intreated to take care of the disbursing of the said summes of money towardes the preparacion aforesaid.

The statement that no masque or show had been presented to the monarch by any Inn since the accession of Charles I (p 240, ll.4–6) means that any Inn of Court masque since 1625 was presented only at home: see the apparent masque at Gray’s Inn, 1631–2 (p 229, ll.5, 9, and endnote). The sale of mock ‘Offices’ (beginning p 240, l.29) must be counted among the more ingenious fund-raising schemes for Christmas revels.

div.head: f 222v(9 February)
div.ab: fforasmuch Order for master Treasourer to disburse moneyes towards the Maske as the moneyes taxed and imposed vpon all the Gentlemen of this Societie by a former Act of parliament of the 12th of November last towardes the defraying of the charge of the masque latelie presented before his Maiestie, will come farre short of soe greate a summe as will bee occasioned thereby, as nowe appeared by the relacion of mr Willis att this parliament, who hath bene imployed and trusted in that [busines] service. And forasmuch as master Treasourer of this howse hath alreadie furnished the said mr Willis with somme moneyes out of the Stock of this howse for that purpose, and there is present occasion for the disbursing of more towardes that service. It is therefore ordered att this parliament That the said master Treasourer may deliver vnto the handes of the said mr Willis out of the stock of the howse such further moneys as hee shall haue occasion to expende and laye out about the same busines, vntill some further course shall bee taken for the raysing of soe greate a summe And that this present Act shall bee a sufficient warrant and discharge to the said master Treasourer as well for all such moneyes as hee hath alreadie deliverd or shall hereafter deliver to the said mr Willis for the purpose aforesaid. The said master Treasourer taking a Receipt or Receipts from the said mr Willis for the same./

div.head: f 223(27 April)
div.ab: Whereas Reference touching the Masqueby an act of parliament made the twelft daye of November last it was ordered that a Rolle shoulde bee made for the raysing of moneyes towardes the defraying of the charge of the masque therein mencioned and sythence presented before his Maiestie, and that the Cheiffe Butler of this howse shoulde collect the moneys due vpon the same Rolle and from tyme to tyme deliver the same soe by him collected vnto the handes of Mr Willis one of the Benchers of this howse for the disbursing thereof in such manner as by the said Act appeareth. And whereas alsoe by another Act of parliament made the nynth daye of ffebruary last, it was ordered (That whereas Master Treasourer of this howse had then formerlie furnished the said Mr Willis with somme moneyes out of the Stock of the howse for that purpose, and that there was then present occasion for disbursing of more towardes that service) That the said Master Treasourer might deliver vnto the handes of the said Mr Willis out of the Stock of the howse such further moneyes as hee should have occasion to expende about the same busines, taking a receipte or receiptes from the said Mr Willis for the same And whereas the said Mr Willis hath receaved not onlie severall summes of money collected vpon the said Rolle from the handes of the Cheiffe Butler of this howse but alsoe the summe of six hundred twentie and six powndes of the said Master Treasourer out of the Stock of this howse by vertue of the said last recited act of parliament to bee imployed towardes the charge of the said Masque. It is therefore att this parliament desired that Mr Trotman Mr Bulstrod and Mr ffarer three of the Benchers of this howse will aswell consider of all the said Mr Willis his receiptes and disbursementes already had and made about the said Masque, and howe and in what manner the same have bene imployed as alsoe what other moneyes they shall conceave necessarie to bee further raysed for the discharge thereof yf it shall appeare vnto them, there is not sufficient in the handes of the said Mr Willis to defraye the same. And that they will report theire opinions to the Boarde touching the same with what convenient speede they maye to the ende such further course may bee taken therein as shall bee thought fitt./

div.head: f 224v(22 June)
div.ab: Whereas Order for Master Treasurer to disburse more money towardes the masque by an Act of parliament made the 27th daye of Aprill last, It was ordered desired that Mr Trotman Mr Bulstrod and Mr ffarrar three of the Benchers of this howse woulde aswell consider of the Receiptes and disbursementes before that tyme had and made by Mr Willis one other of the Benchers of this howse, about the Masque latelie presented before his Maiestie, and howe the same had bene imployed as alsoe what other moneyes they shoulde conceave necessarie to bee further raysed for the discharge thereof, yf it should appeare vnto them there was not sufficient in the handes of the said Mr Willis to defraye the same. Nowe vpon the Report of the said Committees that there is not sufficient in the handes of the said Mr Willis to defraye the said Charge, and that hee will have occasion to disburse one hundred powndes more att the least over and aboue his former Receiptes It is therevpon att this parliament ordered that Master Treasurer of this howse may deliver vnto the said Mr Willis out of the Stock of the howse such further summes of money as there shall bee necessarie occasion to bee disbursed about the defraying of the said charge, taking a Receipte or Receiptes from the said Mr Willis for the same. And it is ordered that this present Act shall bee a sufficient warrant and discharge to the said Master Treasurer in that behalfe./
